For the full correctness yes, but:

we long decided that we don't want to sacrifice performance for metrics (there are other examples of that - here it's not that important, but take a look for example at RecordWriter#numBytesOut or RecordWriter#numBuffersOut, which are on more performance sensitive path)
metrics reading is not critical, even if gets older/incorrect value
I haven't seen problems caused by this so far
the proper solution that wouldn't impact performance as much would be to read the metrics from the mailbox thread (via mailbox action). It would be a zero overhead on the metric collecting path, small and very rare overhead for the task thread during measurement and some extra overhead for the thread asking for metric values (but that's not important)

So I would keep ignoring the problem, until it becomes real, and then go on with the mailbox solution.

During the offline discussion, it seemed the right thing to update the metric here.
But now I'm wondering,  isn't it too late to update it here?
If the 1st checkpoint is delayed for 1 hour, then the metric will report zero-delay for this one hour, right? Is it an issue?
I see the following way to solve this:

introduce pendingCheckpointTimestamp
upon receiving RPC call, update pendingCheckpointTimestamp it from cp metadata and reset latestDelay
upon starting checkpoint, do the opposite: reset pendingCheckpointTimestamp and update latestDelay
in getAsyncCheckpointStartDelayNanos report  now() - pendingCheckpointTimestamp or latestDelay depending on what is set

(probably need to adjust for multiple concurrent checkpoints)

If the 1st checkpoint is delayed for 1 hour, then the metric will report zero-delay for this one hour, right? Is it an issue?

Yes you are right, there will be "blind spot" period while the first checkpoint is still on-going. I think this is fine:

it's the same behaviour as for the network tasks
I think the prime use cases is to look at the statistics of finished/completed checkpoints.

So I wouldn't complicate the code because of that.
